conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the system of three logs in equilibrium.
The arrangement of the three logs forms an isosceles triangle with the top angle ∠O1 = 120°.
The other two angles at O2 and O3 are each 30°.
Consider the free body diagram for log A.
The weight of log A acts vertically downward: WA = mg.
The normal reactions from logs B and C act along the lines joining O1 to O2 and O1 to O3, respectively.
Each reaction force can be resolved into horizontal and vertical components.
The vertical component of each force F balances the weight of A: F = mg/√3.
Consider the free body diagram for log B.
The weight of log B acts vertically downward: WB = mg.
There is a normal reaction from log A, which is F = mg/√3, making an angle of 30° with the horizontal.
The vertical component of the normal reaction from A must balance part of the weight of B: N_ground = mg(1 - 1/2√3).
For the logs to just start sliding, the horizontal component of the normal reaction from A must be balanced by the maximum static friction.
Calculate the dynamic friction coefficient: μ = √3/(2√3 - 1).
The dynamic friction coefficient between the ground and the logs is: √3/(2√3 - 1).
